title: Busy highway bridge suddenly collapses during rush hours in China
text:
A busy highway bridge has collapsed in eastern China during rush hours, according to local media.

The flyover fell apart this evening when cars and trucks drove on it, footage released by state media shows.

The accident took place at 6pm in Wuxi, a major city of Jiangsu Province on China's eastern coast, reported People's Daily through its official social media account.

Footage from Chinese social media platform Weibo shows the moment the highway bridge collapsed in Wuxi this evening. Pictures also show cars being trapped under the structure

The flyover gave way at around 6pm today in Wuxi, a city two hours from Shanghai by car

The overpass is part of the 312 National Expressway.

The section that gave way was along the direction bound for Shanghai, which is about two hours away by car.

The report said some cars which were passing under the bridge were smashed and trapped.

State newspaper Global Times said three cars were stranded under the debris.

One of them had been parked there and was empty, the outlet wrote on Twitter-style Weibo.

Footage released by China's state broadcaster shows firefighting trying to free trapped people

The accident took place in Wuxi (pictured), a city of Jiangsu Province on China's eastern coast

Footage from China's state broadcaster CCTV shows rescue workers trying to free people stuck in a mangled vehicle.

Other dashcam clips show the moment the structure one side of the bridge gave way when cars approached it.

The transport authority of Jiangsu said the accident was likely to have been caused by a 'seriously overloaded' lorry which was driving on it, said China Transport Post.

The authorities are yet to announce if there are any casualties.

The motorway, covering 4,967 kilometres (3,086 miles), runs across China from the east to the west, connecting Shanghai with Xinjiang.
description: The flyover fell apart in Wuxi, China, when cars and trucks drove on it this evening. Local transport authority said the accident was likely to have been caused by a 'seriously overloaded' lorry.
